questions.text: Which of the following is a gold standard measurement of a patient's fitness?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CardioPulmonary Exercise Testing (CPET) CPET is the gold standard measurement of a patient’s fitness.

Highyeild:

CPET (CardioPulmonary Exercise Testing) CPET is the gold standard measurement of a patient’s fitness. The oxygen consumption (VO2) and carbon dioxide production (VCO2) of the patient are measured while they undergo a 10­minute period of incrementally demanding exercise (usually on a cycle ergometer) up to their maximally tolerated level Principle : When a subject’s delivery of O2 to active tissues becomes inadequate, anaerobic metabolism begins; lactate is buffered by bicarbonate and the resulting CO2 increases out of proportion to the escalation in physical difficulty and O2 consumption The ‘anaerobic threshold’ (AT) is the VO2 in mL/kg/min at which this occurs. Peak oxygen consumption is also measured. This is the end product of a subject’s combined fitness Subjects with either an AT below 11 mL/kg/min or a VO2 peak below 15 mL/kg/min are at higher risk of morbidity and mortality after major surgery

Emergency hernia repair (for the repair of a transabdominal defect with leaking ascites) is associated with higher morbidity and mortality. As such, preoperative management and control/ reduction of ascites are paramount for successful hernia repair, long-term durability, and perioperative safety. When hernia repair is pursued, abdominal wall closure with suture (without mesh) is both feasible and safe. Patients with decompensated cirrhosis (CPT-C; high MELD) awaiting liver transplantation would benefit from hernia repair after transplantation and/ or delaying cholecystectomy to the time of liver transplantation

questions.text: Which of the following scoring system comprised only objective measures?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both A & B The MELD score is comprised only of objective measures: total bilirubin (mg/dL), creatinine (mg/dL), and international normalized ratio (INR, %). MELD SCORE : The MELD score is predictive of survival in patients with cirrhosis and was originally developed primarily for transplant selection. In recent years, the MELD score has gradually supplanted the CTP classification for both liver-directed operations and nonhepatic surgical risk stratification. CTP & MELD :

Highyeild:

Unlike the CTP score, which includes subjective components such as encephalopathy and ascites, the MELD score is comprised only of objective measures: total bilirubin (mg/dL), creatinine (mg/dL), and international normalized ratio (INR, %). Thirty-day mortality ranges relatively linearly with MELD score, with MELD <8 associated with 6% mortality, and MELD >20 associated with a greater than 50% mortality. While some studies suggested that a MELD score of 10 to 14 was a better predictor of death or need for transplantation after abdominal surgery than CTP class C, CTP score and ASA classification were predictive of mortality among patients selected for nonhepatic abdominal operations and MELD was not. Overall, the predictive utility of both MELD and CTP scores may be greater for urgent than for elective operations For all patients with cirrhosis, the operative risk increases with higher CPT (B–C) and higher MELD (>18–20).

questions.explanation:
